comment.author: 15885731@N00
comment._content:
I'm going to be talking about  how Flickr relates to archives access in a few weeks - do you think putting this image on Flickr has helped laypeople find this image and use it for their needs, or has it just driven more users to ask for the actual photograph in the National Archives?
Thanks.

comment.author: 35740357@N03
comment._content: Hi photosharp, Thanks including the National Archives in your presentation. So far, anecdotally, we have not seen an increase in requests for reproductions of photographs since we joined the Flickr community. It seems that making photos available on Flickr has allowed the public and researchers to find images like this one of Nixon and Elvis and use them for their needs. Interestingly, althought Nixon and Elvis is the most requested photo at the National Archives, it is not the most viewed on our Flickr photostream. This photo of two women at U.S. Steel in oxygen masks has gotten almost three times as many views (3,064 compared to 1,087 views): www.flickr.com/photos/usnationalarchives/3660777810/. Good luck with your presentation! Thanks, Jill (U.S. National Archives)

comment._content: Both the subjects were famous people with large followings, tremendous gifts, and genuine genius in particular ways, and both destroyed a large part of what was best about themselves.  But I suppose that everyone realizes that.

comment.author: 39037401@N08
comment._content:
If Elvis would have gotten behind the anti-vietnam conflict and
protested, the war would have ended in a snap. People respected
Elvis, saw him as the boy-next-door. Whereas John Lennon was
seen as a deviant and too far the other end avantgard. However,
Elvis believed in the military being a soldier in Korea.

comment.author: 35991403@N07
comment._content:
Politicians don't make policy based on the whims of entertainers.  And why should Elvis have gotten behind something he may not have believed in?

Elvis never served in Korea.  He was drafted into the U.S. Army during peacetime, and was stationed for a period in West Germany.

comment.author: 44381705@N02
comment._content:
"007-ELVIS", & Tricky Dick, it is rumored they were in the oval office singing...that would be a recording to hear...as would any talk of Nixon discouraging 'E' from running for the U.S.Presidency, apparantly Elvis told him he thought he could win with "all his fans". 
It was the high-point of three days The King was on his own without any bodyguards, he even took a few 'coach' flights across the country!
Dick Cavette hosts a movie about the whole story, the VHS video of it is available here, but the DVD is only available in Britain.

comment.author: 67070692@N06
comment._content: My dad said  "In years to come, kids will look in a history book and ask 'What was the matter with this president?', the economy was perfect, we put a man on the moon, and relations with China were never better".
